It supports and strengthens the capacities of the Municipality by considering inclusive approaches as fundamental to improve the urban environment and promote the welfare of all residents while mitigating potential tensions. The technical assistance that ACAV will provide to Koboko Municipality will strengthen its capacities in terms of urban planning and service delivering, thus contributing to increase the safety and well-being of refugees and their host communities and reduce inequalities between these groups. The provision of technical assistance by ACAV will sustain the attempts of the Municipality to implement evidence-based municipal strategies for refugee integration in Koboko and support to vulnerable populations in general as well as to offer better services to its population without distinction between refugees and host communities. The activity plan to reach these objectives will be defined in a full proposal to be outlined by Koboko Municipality with the support of ACAV. At the same time, the technical assistance provided by ACAV will ensure the proper management of EU funds by Koboko Municipality through the strengthening of the municipal up- and down-stream PFM capacities. The reskilling and upskilling of local authorities to improve financial management performance will have a positive impact that will spill over to sectors beyond those of focus under the EUTF Action in Uganda.

title: Strengthened Socio-Economic Development and Better Employment Oppportunities for Refugees and Host Communities in the Jijiga Area
summary: The action aims to trigger systems-level market growth, through targeted interventions, helping to create sustainable, lucrative and decent, employment and self-employment opportunities. By taking a systems approach, market opportunities will be available for host communities and refugees alike. In addition to transforming markets, the action will also address other challenges facing refugees and host communities that are obstacles to improved socio-economic integration, such as access to information, documentation and justice. This will be implemented in close coordination with SO1 of the EU action (SO1 - Enhanced organisational and technical capacity of ARRA, MoFEC, and other relevant Ethiopian government institutions), working with UNHCR and ReDSS to support ARRA and regional and local government in providing services at the local level.

title: Ethiopia Job Compact Sector Reform and Performance Contract
summary:
**The intervention logic** of this action is that if the Government of Ethiopia succeeds in developing sustainable industrialisation - which includes making important efforts in developing the private sector, promoting investments, maintaining stable macro-economic policies, and progressing in the decent work agenda - and it fulfils its pledges on  refugee self-reliance and refugee mobility (made in the context of the CRRF), there will be more employment opportunities to Ethiopians and refugees, and this will contribute to the reduction of irregular migration from Ethiopia.  

​

title: Agribusiness in Eastern Sudan RDPP
summary:
The action aims to enhance income-generating opportunities for refugees and host communities in the predominantly agricultural economy of Eastern Sudan. The action focuses on obstacles for starting or extending businesses, low productivity of agriculture and obstacles for disadvantaged groups in economic participation.

The proposed action seeks to lower the risks for entrepreneurs to invest and/or engage in new (agricultural) economic activities. Eastern Sudan has a relatively vibrant business community. Entrepreneurs are willing and able to invest in new activities, especially in value chain improvement. The proposed action is demand driven: starting points are the initiatives and business ideas of the Sudanese entrepreneurs. In a series of workshops that include training, mentoring and coaching some 2000 members of the disadvantaged groups and entrepreneurs as well as 80 associations are given the opportunity to engage in economic activities that comprise all links in the agricultural value chains

title: Fostering smallholders capacity and access to markets in food insecure areas of Darfur
summary:
The overall objective of the project is to enhance the food and income security of smallholder farming households in Darfur. The specific objectives of the project are to: i) Increase household food availability by reducing pre-farm gate losses; ii) Empower smallholders to sell surplus grain at higher prices; iii) Strengthen capacity of smallholders and farmer’s groups to access markets and value chains.
 2
 This intervention represents a pilot approach aiming to develop a model for Post-Harvest Loss reduction in Darfur. Over 21,700 farmers are to be reached in each state targeted by this Action to ensure that the model developed can be tested, amended and replicated across the range of contexts that exist for smallholder farmers in Darfur. At least 40% of the direct beneficiaries will be women1 (feasibility will be verified during inception phase, based on the situation on the terrain). Indirect beneficiaries are estimated at 325,5002. Participation will be open to resident farmers, IDPs who have access to land and returnees (both former refugees and IDPs, currently estimated at 115,000 in South Darfur, 2,773 in West Darfur and 23,793 in Central Darfur) with the exact mix varying across localities and states and to be determined through applying the targeting criteria.The intervention logic assumes that rural development can address factors that compel people to move by creating business opportunities and jobs for young people. It can also lead to increased food security, more resilient livelihoods, better access to social protection, reduced conflict over natural resources and solutions to environmental degradation and climate change.
 The geographical scope of the project focuses on South Darfur, West Darfur, and Central Darfur States. Indicatively the 11 following localities will be targeted: Nyala locality, Beleile, Al Salam and Gereida (South Darfur), Zoom, Zalengi, Muktar and Bendisi (West Darfur) Habila, Geneina and Krenick (Central Darfur)

title: Youth Employment skills (yes)
summary: This project aims to economically empower youth and disadvantaged groups among host communities, refugees and IDPs in Darfur, thus providing the national economy with employable skilled professionals. The specific objective of the project is to improve the ability of young women and men to find employment or establish and grow their businesses through expanding and improving market oriented, equitable (also removing regional inequities) and gender-balanced Technical Vocational Education and Training (TVET).

title: South Sudan Rural Development: Strengthening smallholders’ resilience in Northern Bahr el-Ghazal
summary: The overall objective of the project is to contribute to strengthening the resilience of communities, improving governance and conflict prevention, and reducing forced displacements due to loss of livelihoods. The project main objectives include: (i) to improve food security of rural smallholders in Northern Bahr el-Ghazal; and (ii) to empower communities to cope with environmental volatility and insecurity.
partner_funding: Food and Agriculture Organization, EU Trust Fund for Africa

title:
South Sudan Rural Development: Strengthening
Smallholders’ Resilience in Greater Upper Nile"
summary:
The project addresses the SORUDEV SSR program’s priorities and themes, notably strengthening individual and community resilience by improving production and nutrition (food diversification) and food hygiene awareness; establishing conflict mitigation and resilience mechanisms, including through strengthening the capacity of local institutions in natural resource management, DRR preparedness and conflict arbitration and resolution techniques; to increase household income in the targeted locations. 

General objective:  Contribute to strengthening resilience of communities, improving governance of natural resources and conflict prevention and reducing forced displacements due to loss of livelihoods in GUN Region. 

Specific objectives:  

1. To improve the food security of rural smallholders in Greater Upper Nile and 

2. To empower them to cope with environmental volatility and insecurity.
partner_funding: International Rescue Committee, EU Trust Fund for Africa
partner_extending: Cordaid, ZOA

title:
Food security & Resilience in Transitioning Environments -
FORESITE
summary:
The Action has been designed to address many of the immediate, underlying and basic causes of low resilience in Greater Bahr el Ghazal. 

The general objective: to contribute to strengthening resilience of communities, improving governance and conflict prevention and reduced forced displacements due to loss of livelihoods. 

The specific objective "To improve food security of rural smallholders in Greater Bahr el Ghazal and to empower them to cope with environmental volatility and insecurity" will be achieved through the following results: 

1) Reduced barriers to engagement in resilience building, food security and income generating activities, especially for women and youth; 

2) Increased anticipatory, absorptive, and adaptive capacity with respect to climate change and disruptive events including natural disasters and conflict; and 

3) Improved longer-term food security and income especially for women and youth. The action targets both smallholder farmer households (primarily through Farmer Groups) and more vulnerable households (landless, female-headed, IDPs/returnees.
partner_funding: EU Trust Fund for Africa, World Vision Australia
partner_extending: World Vision South Sudan, Fondazione AVSI, Norwegian Refugee Council

title: Innovative durable solutions for IDPs and returnees in Mogadishu through enhanced governance, employment and access to basic and protective services
summary: The project is a joint UN initiative by the UNHCR, UN-Habitat and UNDP, complemented with the expertise of the NGOs CESVI, SWDC and SIDO. The purpose of the project is to sustainably address the protracted displacement of IDPs and the situation of refugee returnees in Mogadishu through a strategic approach facilitating durable solution processes and enhancing the sustainability thereof. The project involves various innovative approaches towards addressing displacement and furthering durable solutions.

title: EU Flight Services to Somalia Contract under the ECHO Framework Contract
summary: To provide air transport services to and within Somalia to support the continued cooperation and engagement of EU and other like-minded donors.
partner_implementing: 748 Air Services Ltd, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Programme for Local Governance - JPLG III
partner_implementing: United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Capital Development Fund, OIT - ILO - Organisation Internationale du Travail - International Labour Organization, UNICEF, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Security Sector Governance programme - JSSGP
summary:
The Somalia Joint Security Sector Governance Programme (JSSGP) is a 24-month programme supporting the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) and Federal Member States (FMS) security institutions to improve peace, security and safety, enhancing civilian oversight and in accordance with the rule of law and human rights. This support is in line with the National Security Architecture and the Roadmap on Security and Justice.

To support Federal Government   of Somalia (FGS) and Federal Member States (FMS) security institutions to   function better in order to improve peace, security and safety, enhance   political and civilian oversight, and the rule of law for Somalis.  

1. Federal security   institutions have increased professional capacity to exercise political and   civilian oversight, deliver security services and coordinate the Federal   approach to security in accordance with their mandates and in compliance with   human rights standards.  

2. Federal Member State   security institutions have increased professional capacity to exercise   oversight and deliver security services in accordance with their mandates and   in compliance with human rights standards.

3. Federal and Federal   Member State legislatures have increased professional capacity to exercise   oversight in accordance with their mandates.

​
partner_implementing: United Nations Development Programme, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Rule of Law Programme in Somaliland
summary:
Sustainable models developed for the   effective delivery of rights-based, inclusive and accountable rule of law and   security and being implemented across regions in Somaliland.

 1. Rights-respecting   and accountable basic justice services increased in piloted areas.

2. Rights-respecting   and accountable basic policing services increased in piloted areas.

3. Parole and   probation services to help the sustainable management of corrections   facilities developed and piloted.

4. Security Sector   Governance enhanced.

5. Co-ordination of   the rule of law and security sectors improved at leadership and delivery   levels
partner_implementing: United Nations Development Programme, United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women, United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Corrections Programme - JCP
summary:
Outcome 1: Somali Custodial Corps increasingly provides fair, humane and human rights compliant services to the Somali
Outcome 2: Community actors are participating in the improvement of prisoner welfare and community reintegration
partner_implementing: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Corrections Programme - JCP
summary:
Outcome 1: Somali Custodial Corps increasingly provides fair, humane and human rights compliant services to the Somali

Outcome 2: Community actors are participating in the improvement of prisoner welfare and community reintegration
partner_implementing: United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Justice Programme - JJP
summary:
Outcome 1 focuses on federalization, state and institution building and support to the formal justice sector. Support will continue at the national level to build a federal architecture, policy and legislation and resources will also be allocated to developing new institutions and basic service delivery in the Federal Member States.

Outcome 2 focuses on ‘bottom-up’, community driven security and justice initiatives. This complements the work under Outcome 1, which is predominantly based on ‘top-down’ capacity building of State institutions to strengthen the operation of the formal justice system. This outcome is focused on the delivery of basic services to the communities to increase access to justice, particularly for women, children and IDPs, guarantee better protection of individuals’ rights and those at higher risk of insecurity, and provide a credible alternative to Al-Shabab courts as part of the P/CVE strategy. It will implement a number of pilot projects which will be expanded if successful. Success will be measured through a strong M&E framework.
partner_implementing: International Development Law Organisation, United Nations Development Programme, EU Delegation Somalia

title: Joint Justice Programme - JJP
summary:
Outcome 1 focuses on federalization, state and institution building and support to the formal justice sector. Support will continue at the national level to build a federal architecture, policy and legislation and resources will also be allocated to developing new institutions and basic service delivery in the Federal Member States.

Outcome 2 focuses on ‘bottom-up’, community driven security and justice initiatives. This complements the work under Outcome 1, which is predominantly based on ‘top-down’ capacity building of State institutions to strengthen the operation of the formal justice system. This outcome is focused on the delivery of basic services to the communities to increase access to justice, particularly for women, children and IDPs, guarantee better protection of individuals’ rights and those at higher risk of insecurity, and provide a credible alternative to Al-Shabab courts as part of the P/CVE strategy. It will implement a number of pilot projects which will be expanded if successful. Success will be measured through a strong M&E framework.

​
partner_implementing: International Development Law Organisation, United Nations Development Programme, EU Delegation Somalia

title: South Sudan Health Pooled Fund (HPF 3)
summary: The Health Pooled Fund (HPF3) will reduce maternal and under -five mortality rates in South Sudan, through (i) the delivery of a basic package of health and nutrition services; (ii) promoting community engagement in health as a public good; (iii) supporting local health systems stabilisation.

title: South Sudan COVID-19 preparedness and response
summary: This project supports diagnostic laboratories as a prerequisite to combating existing and emerging infections of local, regional, or global interest, including Covid-19.
partner_funding: WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION (WHO), EU Trust Fund for Africa

title:
Humanitarian-Development Nexus: Strengthening preparedness and
response of the health system addressing the COVID-19 Pandemic in
Sudan
summary:
This aim of this project is to sustainably strengthen the health system in Sudan for epidemic preparedness and response addressing the needs of the COVID-19 pandemic in the the country.

Since there was a clear need to continue providing support to a COVID-19 response in Sudan that addresses the ongoing crisis and provides elements of a sustainable strengthening of the health system and epidemiological preparedness and response, a top-up of €10.2 million to this project was approved in September 2020.
partner_funding: World Health Organization (2), EU Trust Fund for Africa
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: EU Support to the United Nations ‘One UN Response Plan to COVID-19 in Nigeria’
summary: The European Union (EU), as well as other donors, will support the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) to implement a ‘One UN Response Plan to COVID-19 in Nigeria’, with the objective to ensuring optimum care of the confirmed COVID-19 cases and contain further spread of the outbreak through an inclusive and nationally-owned COVID-19 response from a shared vision and a common strategy, based on the best international practice of similar processes in other countries. Its purpose is to coordinate and align collective efforts in partnership with the government, Civil Society Organisations (CSOs), private sector, international and national stakeholders with the aim to increase the availability, accessibility, affordability, adaptability and acceptability of COVID-19 response services in Nigeria. This is in recognition that a collaborative engagement is urgently required to amplify Government’s efforts to respond to COVID-19 given the multifaceted nature of the crisis and the potentially unprecedented implications to socioeconomic conditions in an already complex Humanitarian-Development-Peace (H-D-P) nexus context.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: GAR-SI (Groupes d’Action Rapides – Surveillance et Intervention au Sahel) - Chad
summary: Le programme contribuera au renforcement des capacités opérationnelles des autorités nationales pour permettre un contrôle effectif du territoire et élargir l´action de l´État de droit à l´ensemble du Sahel en créant des unités policières robustes, flexibles, mobiles, multidisciplinaires et autosuffisantes qui permettent un contrôle adéquat du territoire.

title: EU support for the Family Support Programme and for the consolidation of social protection in Sudan
summary:
The Government of Sudan has solicited donor support to gear up short-term social assistance through a Family Support Programme (FPS), viewed as a central facet of its response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and as a foundation for its future long-term social protection system. The aim of the action is therefore to support social assistance through Governmental channels, so as to help the Transition Government in implementing the above-mentioned FSP with a view to mitigate the immediate impacts of COVID-19, while at the same time establishing a robust long-term inclusive social protection system.

To further support the action, on top of the initial €45 million foreseen for the programme, additional funds were approved in July 2021 (€20 million, bringing the total of the action to €65 million). The additional amount proposed is expected to enlarge Objective 1 of the action, namely delivering immediate social assistance and cash mitigation to households (cash transfers), including women, refugees, displaced people and people with disabilities.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Dulqaad iyo wada hadal - Promoting a culture of tolerance and dialogue in Somalia
summary: This action will address instability and violent extremism in Somalia as a main driver of forced displacement in and outside the country. It will do so by facilitating community outreach and promoting more tolerance, dialogue and peaceful values, as well as supporting the efforts from the Federal Government to develop a policy for countering violent extremism. The action will be implemented nation-wide, with a focus on those areas where the EU is already investing in basic service delivery and livelihoods.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Somalia State and Resilience Building Contract
summary: The action directly responds to objectives 2 and 4 of the Trust Fund, priority domains 1 of the Valletta Action Plan, and Sustainable Development Goals 1, 16 and 17.  The intervention logic of this action is that if the Somali federal state is increasingly legitimate and capacitated, and that the Somali federal project is consolidated, the government of Somalia will be able to continue on its path of reforms, and thus build a strong track record for international financial institutions (IFIs)' arrears clearance and Highly Indebted Poor Countries Initiative (HIPC)  Decision point, as well as be in a position to deliver more services to its population.

title: Humanitarian Development Nexus: Simple, Spatial, Survey Method (S3M) for Sudan
summary: Sudan S3M-II will avail information about nutrition, WASH and health status at locality and sub-locality levels and to map information to monitor trends, reorient ongoing multi-sectoral efforts to reduce stunting, combat acute malnutrition and improve health status of Sudanese communities focusing on delivering services to the most in need areas. UNICEF and the Ministry of Health (MoH) will collaboratively work in 18 Sudan states to organize, collect and analyse data and produce the S3M-II report. This will be followed by dissemination and use of findings.

title: Implementation of Sudan-Europe Creative Connections initiative
summary: Implementation of a multiannual training program for Sudanese fashion designers and organise a public showcase of their productions. Implementation a multiannual training program for Sudanese musicians and organise a showcasing event of new musical productions. Implementation a multiannual training program for Sudanese film makers, and organise three editions of the Sudan-Europe Film Festival. Production of a collection of illustrated storybooks for children and  dissemination in schools. Production an  interactive guide to be implemented in the Khartoum National Antiquities Museum

title: LIVESTOCK EPIDEMIO-SURVEILLANCE PROJECT TO SUPPORT LIVELIHOODS OF VULNERABLE RURAL SMALLHOLDERS AND PASTORALISTS (LESP SLSP)
summary: The intervention logic of the project is that by strengthening the resilience of pastoralist population – particularly in the South Eastern regions bordering with Ethiopia and South Sudan – a significant number of small scale farmers engaged in animal farming, will significantly improve their livelihoods, thus reducing forced migration. The well-being of livestock is crucial to enhance the resilience of pastoralist population. Indeed, the targeted regions are affected by uncontrolled migratory movements of livestock which bear the risk of outbreaks of animal diseases. The uncontrolled migratory movements result in higher livestock mortality and morbidity rates that limit livestock productivity at farmers' levels and impedes livestock trade and export. Insufficient epidemio-surveillance and disease control are the major causes to these problems and will therefore been tackled by the present programme.

title: Sustainable reintegration support to Ethiopian returnees from Europe
summary: To be completed
partner_implementing: Administration for Refugees and Returnees Affairs

title: Shire alliance: energy access for host communities and refugees in Ethiopia
summary: The overall objective of this action is to improve the living conditions in the refugee camps and host communities by enhancing local capacity, creating livelihood opportunities, and improving the access to basic services using the cross-cutting impacts of energy. The action will be implemented following two main components. Firstly, it will improve the delivery of electricity through capacity building of EEU, refugees and host communities, improvement and extension of the electrical grid and installation of street lighting in refugee camps and host communities. It will enhance the capacity building of local entities, EEU, host communities and refugees to manage and operate the previous energy services. To this aim, innovative learning programmes will be developed for the different stakeholders both at theoretical and practical level. This action will give special attention to transfer these learning programmes to local entities in order to ensure their replication in the future. Secondly, it will create livelihood opportunities and improve the quality of life of refugees and host communities through capacity building, creation of businesses based on solar technology and distribution of Solar Home Systems, fostering employment and economic development. For this purpose, it will enhance the creation of business related with the energy services covered by the action (in this case solar energy), shared by host communities and refugees. There will be specific training and support for this process too. The aim of this capacity-building component is to guarantee the sustainability of the intervention once the implementation period is over. Coordination with local authorities involved in energy, education and gender issues will be crucial for the success of the intervention. In this sense, there have been already consultations at field level to promote their participation since the beginning of the project.
partner_implementing: Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation

title: Capacity building and technical assistance to a Comprehensive Refugee Response Framework (CRRF) structure and Ethiopian government institutions
summary: This action aims to support the GoE to shift from a "care and maintenance" to an approach which emphasises refugee self reliance , refugee mobility in the country and the integration of refugees into national and regional development processes. Framed within the Ethiopian National Action Plan for the implementation of the CRRF, based on NY Declaration, this action focuses on the pledges related to local integration  of refugees in protracted displacement and the expansion of the OCP, as well as pledges on access to employment and work permits, education and all others benefits to which a foreigner with a permanent legal residence is entitled.

title: Youth empowerment for successful transitions to decent work in Amhara and Somali regions of Ethiopia
summary: The project will support and enable 9,000 vulnerable young men and women from wag himra and siti zones to acquire the required knowledge, skills, behaviour and attitudes which will help them to access safer and non-discriminatory wage based employment opportunities. Enhancing this, the action will engage multiple actors to come together and work in a coordinated manner towards this goal, involving the public and private sectors to support and develop decent entry-level work opportunities for vulnerable young men and women, and for beneficiaries to know about and take advantage of the job opportunities that do exist.

title: Improving access to safely managed water supply in the resilience building program for Ethiopia (RESET II)
summary: This project has three main outcomes: 1.	To produce Woreda based hydrogeological maps which other partners can use for developing groundwater resources to improve drilling success rates 2.	16 deep boreholes drilled based on geohydrological overlay maps and field-based geophysical assessment, functional and sustainably managed by capable and skilled communities 3.	Promotion of knowledge management and dissemination of the groundwater resources mapping exercise and resources among the main WASH stakeholders in Ethiopia. The proposed project will be implemented within 36 months in 41 Woredas in eight RESET Clusters in Amhara, Afar, Somali, Oromia and SNNP Regions of Ethiopia. The project is designed based on critical need in the sector and it is in line with the ongoing One WASH National Programme (OWNP) as well as UNICEF's 2016/2020 WASH Country Programme priorities. It will also ensure synergy with RESET II through the active participation and engagement of the EU Delegation and RESET II partners at all levels.

title: RESILIENCE BUILDING AND CREATION OF ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES IN ETHIOPIA (RESET II) : CRISIS MODIFIER FUND
summary: The Crisis Modifier Mechanism (CMM) contributes to the overall objectives of the EU RESET program and aims to address the immediate, lifesaving and essential needs of all the EU RESET sectors and geographical areas affected by a crisis.  Additionally, the CMM will enhance EU RESET programming by responding to emergencies while simultaneously preserving established programming. As EU RESET programming targets areas which are highly vulnerable to disasters, the risk of shock during implementation is high and requires ongoing monitoring to ensure implementation.

title: INNOVATION IN WATER DEVELOPMENT BORENA ZONE OROMOYA REGIONAL STATE (RESET II)
summary: The Innovations in Water Development (IWD) initiative builds on CARE’s RESET II Promoting Resilient Livelihoods programme by adding additional investment in water development. IWD aims to increase access to water for 21,000 people through expanded water services. These new services will include both new and rehabilitated water services. The new services will be managed by new management groups and linked to other services were possible/feasible, for example linked to Health service facilities.

title: RESTE: LOT3 Travaux de réalisation et de réhabilitation de forages productifs pour hydraulique villageoise et forages hydrauliques semi-urbaine
summary: Travaux de réalisation et de réhabilitation de forages  productifs pour hydraulique villageoise et forages hydrauliques  semi-urbaine dans les sous-préfectures de Mani, Massakory, Massaguet

title: RESTE: LOT 2 Travaux de réalisation et de réhabilitation de forages productifs pour hydraulique villageoise et forages hydrauliques semi-urbaine
summary: Réalisation de forages productifs pour hydraulique villageoise et forages hydraulique semi-urbaine

title: Programme de développement inclusif dans les zones d'accueil (DIZA) – zone Est
summary:
**L'objectif générale** de ce projet est d'améliorer les conditions de vie des populations hôtes et de réfugiés/retournés dans les zones d’accueil.

Les Objectifs Spécifiques sont les suivantes:

OS1 : Soutenir l’accès aux services de base et aux mécanismes de protection sociale pour toutes les populations (locales, retournées et réfugiées).

OS2 : Renforcer la création d'opportunités économiques et d'emplois afin de donner aux populations les moyens de parvenir à l’autosuffisance économique et à la sécurité alimentaire et nutritionnelle.

OS3 : Renforcer les mécanismes de concertation locale entre populations, autorités locales, secteur privé, services techniques et parties prenantes.
partner_implementing: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

title: Towards a Holistic Approach to Labour Migration Governance and Labour Mobility in North Africa
summary:
The Action is designed as a sub-regional programme aiming for the strengthening of migrant workers’ protection mechanisms throughout the migration cycle and whether workers are leaving the region or seeking employment there.

Planned over 36 months, it covers **three countries: Egypt, Morocco and Tunisia **and will be inclusive of and open to other North Africa countries for sub-regional activities. The Action is aligned to existing policy frameworks at global (Sustainable Development Goals, Global Compact for Safe, Orderly, and Regular Migration) and regional (African Union Migration Policy Framework Plan of Action 2018-2030) levels and factored in preliminary consultations with relevant national stakeholders conducted in the preparation phase.
partner_funding: EU Trust Fund for Africa, Bundesministerium fur wirtschaftliche Zusammenarbeit und Entwicklung
partner_accountable: EU Delegation to Tunisia, EU Delegation to Egypt, EU Delegation to Morocco
partner_implementing: International Organization for Migration, OIT - ILO - Organisation Internationale du Travail - International Labour Organization

title: Scale-up of programme “Managing mixed migration flows in Libya” - local governance and socio-economic development pillar
summary:
The proposed action falls under the North of Africa Window of the European Union Trust Fund for stability and addressing the root-causes of irregular migration and displaced persons in Africa (EUTF – NoA). It builds on the approach and the objectives set under the 'local governance and socio-economic development Pillar' of the programme ‘Managing mixed migration flows in Libya through supporting local socio-economic development’ (T05-EUTF-NOA-LY-03), building up existing and expanding existing activities with additional funding. More specifically, it is a scale-up of the initiatives ‘Support to municipalities in Libya (SML)’ currently implemented by the GIZ, and ‘Resilience building for vulnerable children in Libya, including host communities, migrant and refugee children’ currently implemented by UNICEF.

In line with the EUTF-NoA priorities, the Overall Objective of this action is to contribute to the community stabilization efforts in Libya through improving local governance in the framework of (i) the implementation of the decentralization policy, and (ii) an improved access for vulnerable children to qualitative and inclusive child protection and education services in Libya.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: EU-IOM Joint Initiative in North Africa - Top up to Voluntary Humanitarian Return and Reintegration Assistance
summary: This new Action aims to provide an additional indicative number of 15,000 vulnerable or stranded migrants with voluntarily return assistance. The Action is expected to mainly support voluntary humanitarian returns from Libya to their country of origin. In line with the principles of the EU-IOM Joint Initiative, returning migrants should be provided with access to reintegration support in their countries of origin. For those returning to a country where there is no EU-IOM reintegration project in place, reintegration assistance will also be provided through this project.  This represents an estimated percentage of 10% or more (i.e. 1,500 or more) of the number of migrants assisted to return. This Action comes as a top up to the EU-IOM Joint Initiative for Migrant Protection and Reintegration in North Africa and will be implemented by the International Organization for Migration (IOM), under which it is expected that the targeted caseload for voluntary return assistance will be exhausted by the end of 2019 or early 2020 if the current pace of voluntary returns is sustained. Reintegration assistance of migrants returning through this Action to countries in the other two windows of the EUTF (Sahel and Lake Chad and Horn of Africa) as soon as channelled through the Joint Initiative in these two regions if additional funding can be identified.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Appui aux actions des autorités marocaines contre les réseaux facilitant les flux migratoires irréguliers
summary:
La présente action est proposée dans le cadre du Fonds Fiduciaire d’Urgence de l’Union européenne en faveur de la stabilité et de la lutte contre les causes profondes de la migration irrégulière et du phénomène des personnes déplacées en Afrique, volet Afrique du Nord (FFU-AdN).

L’action s’inscrit dans le dialogue migration et mobilité relancé avec le Maroc; elle vise à renforcer les capacités des institutions marocaines, et en particulier du Ministère de l'Intérieur (MI), dans la lutte contre le trafic de migrants et la traite d’êtres humains, incluant un renforcement de la gestion intégrée des frontières au Maroc, conformément au programme 81 de la Stratégie Nationale de l’Immigration et de l’Asile au Maroc (SNIA). Par ailleurs, cette action renforcera le dialogue avec le Maroc sur la migration, notamment dans le domaine des efforts concernant la sensibilisation sur les risques associés à la migration irrégulière des jeunes et des mineurs non accompagnés.

Les actions qui seront appuyées sont basées sur les « Lignes directrices pour un plan d’action de renforcement de la stratégie opérationnelle de lutte contre le trafic illicite de migrants et la traite d’êtres humains » élaborée par le Ministère de l’Intérieur (MdI) du Royaume du Maroc, comme partie prenante clé pour atteindre les objectifs précités.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Building Self-Reliance in Northern Uganda
summary:
The proposed Action (or the Project) will be carried out by a consortium formed by Action Against Hunger (ACF), the Lead, Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), Welthungerhilfe (WHH) and PALM CORPS (Promoters of Agriculture and Linkages to Market) a local NGO. The four organizations have a presence in all the targeted Districts, with ongoing projects providing on- and off-farm livelihoods support, skills development, financial literacy, and value chain development services among refugees and host population.  The overall objective of the project is to strengthen local authorities' coordination and development and local authority-led service delivery to all people in the refugee-hosting districts and to enable greater resilience and self-reliance among both refugee and host communities. 

The specific objective will directly contribute to the global objective by increasing the economic self-reliance of refugees and host populations. As per the theory of change developed by the consortium partners, the 6 following Expected Outputs have been designed to enable the achievement of the specific objective: O1. Increased financial inclusion of refugees and host populations and linkages created to formal and non-formal saving and credit-based interventions; O2. Enhanced carrying capacity of allocated land for refugees and increased food productivity and diversification all year-round; O3. Improved production, productivity and added value (local processing) of nutritious agricultural products for local and regional markets; O4. Small service providers/craft persons supported through flexible demand, market-oriented skills training. O5. Increased access to private sector jobs and internship opportunity; O6. Strengthened value chains and market linkages for both refugees and host communities.

title: EU OPM Sudan – Support to the Office of the Prime Minister
summary: After three decades of authoritarian regime, Sudan has embarked on a difficult political transition. On the basis of the Constitutional Agreement reached in Khartoum (17 August 2019), the country is now led by a civilian-led Government. Within it, there are 16 civilians – including the Prime Minister – and two military. The transition represents a critical opportunity to meet the legitimate aspirations of the Sudanese population for a more peaceful, prosperous and inclusive country.  The EU is firmly committed to back the transition politically and economically. This support is expected to contribute to the stabilisation of the country and its inclusive development, thereby addressing the root-causes of migration.  The overall objective of this project is, therefore, to contribute to the democratic transition in Sudan.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Enhancing protection, lifesaving assistance and sustainable solutions for evacuees from Libya through the Emergency Transit Mechanism (ETM) in Rwanda
summary:
This project will support the activities of UNHCR in providing protection and emergency assistance as well as durable solutions to refugees and asylum-seekers in Libya through emergency evacuation to Rwanda. It aims to provide a multi-sectoral response for refugees and asylum seekers at risk in urban areas and those being held in Libyan detention centres. UNHCR expects to provide transit support to approximately 1,500 persons over 16 months from September 2019 through December 2020.

To increase support to the ETM in Rwanda, in June 2020 a top-up of €2.5 million was approved.
partner_funding: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, EU Trust Fund for Africa
partner_implementing: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Delivering durable solutions to forced displacement in the IGAD region through the implementation of the global compact on refugees (GCR)
summary: This project supports the regional application of the Global Compact on Refugees (GCR) and its Comprehensive Refugee Response Framework (CRRF) via the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD). It aims to provide a political framework to underpin and further enhance reforms and programmes. The project seeks to ensure there are better links between regional and national action. Moreover, it seeks to help the IGAD process address all refugees in the region in the context of the Djibouti Declaration on education for refugees, returnees and host communities, as well as the Kampala Declaration on Jobs, Livelihoods and Self-reliance. Focus is placed on maintaining asylum space and protection, and providing assistance and delivering durable solutions while combining efforts in countries of asylum and origin.
recipient_country: DJ, ER, ET, KE, SD, SO, SS, UG
location_code: UG, SS, SD, KE, ET, ER, DJ, SO
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Response to Increased Environmental Degradation and Promotion of Alternative Energy Sources in Refugee Hosting Districts
summary: In Uganda, increasing environmental degradation in refugee hosting areas has become a major obstacle to effectively sustaining the refugee-hosting model. Environmental protection and restoration has increasingly become a priority. The most visible and immediate impact of the environmental degradation is loss of forest cover and vegetation in refugee-hosting areas. The rapid growth of the refugee population in Uganda has led to a surge in demand for natural resources, including wood fuel, construction material along with an increase in demand for energy-saving stoves and alternative energy-saving techniques and practices. It is against this background that the Government of Uganda has prioritised a response plan to provide the much needed framework for integrated planning and implementation of environment related activities in refugee-hosting districts. This EU project will be a direct, fully aligned and explicit development contribution to the implementation of the response plan. The overall objective of this project is to increase environmental protection and restoration, as well as to improve sustainable energy access. This should lead to an improvement in livelihoods and rights among displaced populations and their host communities in refugee hosting areas.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: EU Support for a Social Protection System in Sudan
summary: The project aims to support the new civilian-led government in Sudan to establish a robust social protection system, and also channel limited funds through existing and pilot social protection mechanisms.  The project responds to the priorities of the recently formed, civilian-led Government of Sudan to a) enhance social protection systems and b) to test and establish means to mitigate the consequences of anticipated economic reforms in the country. With the programme, the EU seeks to support the Transition Government to build a long-term inclusive rights-based social protection system.
partner_implementing: World Bank, OIT - ILO - Organisation Internationale du Travail - International Labour Organization, UNICEF
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Integrated Measures to promote rural-urban value addition and Employment (IMPROVE-EU) – East Sudan
South Sudan Rural Development: feeder roads to strengthen the livelihoods and resilience of rural communities
summary:
This Action seeks to improve the feeder road networks and infrastructure in rural areas with agricultural potential. The logic of this is that enhanced connectivity generates multiplier effects that trigger increase in private sector presence and access to markets, thereby spurring smallholder farmers to produce. This action, firstly approved in December 2019, has been designed to complement, build synergies and to capitalise on the achievements of previous and ongoing EU funded interventions in the former States of Northern and Western Bahr El Ghazal (BEG) in South Sudan, where rural infrastructures have been developed with the EU support.

In spite of the renewed framework for peace, stability and economic growth offered by the constitution of the Revitalised Transitional Government of National Unity constituted in February 2020, South Sudan remains in crisis. With the progressive deterioration of the national economy and the rise in intercommunal conflicts and criminality, combined with the impact of Covid-19 on livelihoods and food supply, climatic shocks and other natural threats, more than 60 percent of the population will face severe acute food insecurity in 2021, with six counties classified as famine-likely. Against this backdrop, a top-up of €20 million was approved in July 2021 to mitigate and prevent the famine risks bringing the total to €36 million.

Most of new funding (€16 million) would increase the food security and resilience component to reinforce the activities in the original States of Bahr El Ghazal, with an increased focus on highly food insecure areas and to expand the intervention to selected locations in the Greater Upper Nile region, following a Human-Development-Peace nexus approach. The remaining €4 million will top-up to the infrastructure component implemented by UNOPS in the original States of Bahr El Ghazal for further improving connectivity, access to markets, water and basic services.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: South Sudan Women Empowerment
summary: This project aims to complement the efforts of the EU and its Member States present in South Sudan to implement the Gender Action Plan II (2016-2020). As this is the first EU Action specifically targeting women and girls in South Sudan, particular attention is sought to ensure a coordinated approach and to highlight EU's added value. The target beneficiaries of this Action are women and girls, particularly in rural communities, with a focus on those who are in the most vulnerable situations (women head of household, women and girls with disabilities, displaced women, survivor of sexual violence in conflict, etc.). The intervention logic is that by building and reinforcing capacities of key actors (duty bearers, rights holders, civil society organisations, etc.) for women and girls’ empowerment, the "gender gap" (work towards gender equality) can be narrowed and communities will become more prosperous and peaceful.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Strengthening Eritrea's National Statistics and Macroeconomic Statistics Systems (SENSS)
summary: This project seeks to strengthen the economic governance capacity of the Government of the State of Eritrea (GSE). The aim is for Eritrea to have a sound, capable and self-reliant National Statistics System (NSS) by the end of the programme. Statistical data is the foundation for development policy, through which investment and private sector development can be encouraged. This programme therefore targets a core issue that has an end goal of improving development outcomes for all Eritreans. Strong data collection capacity will contribute to promotion of economic growth and good governance.
partner_funding: EU Trust Fund for Africa, United Nations Development Programme
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Reconnecting Eritrea and Ethiopia through rehabilitation of the main arterial roads in Eritrea – Phase 2
summary: The project aims to rehabilitate the main arterial roads in Eritrea along the Eritrea-Ethiopia trade corridor (Massawa - Nefasit - Ser'ha - Zelambesa) in order to help reinforce peace and economic integration between Eritrea and Ethiopia. Following the historic peace agreement between Eritrea and Ethiopia in July 2018, reconnecting the two countries and providing Ethiopia access to Eritrea’s ports is a key priority. This will help to boost both countries’ economies, increase regional economic integration and generate job opportunities.
partner_implementing: The United Nations Office for Project Services (UNOPS)
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: CRRF: Inclusive Urban Development and Mobility
summary: This project aims to help counties in the Horn of Africa address the dual challenge of the rising number of displaced people being hosted in urban areas (urban displacement) and wider urbanisation. It will focus on regional dialogue and fostering peer networks and knowledge exchange on the challenges and opportunities relating to urban displacement in the context of urbanisation. As part of this project, two pilot actions will provide direct support to urban areas, with severely stressed or pre-existing low coverage of basic services and a high concentration of refugees.
project_parent: EU Trust Fund for Africa Results Framework

title: Enhancing protection, lifesaving assistance and sustainable solutions for evacuees from Libya through the Emergency Transit Mechanism (ETM) in Rwanda
summary: This action will support the activities of UNHCR in providing protection and emergency assistance as well as durable solutions to refugees and asylum-seekers in Libya through emergency evacuation to Rwanda. It aims to provide a multi-sectoral response for refugees and asylum seekers at risk in urban areas and those being held in Libyan detention centres. UNHCR expects to provide transit support under the ETM to approximately 1,500 persons.

title: Partenariat Opérationnel Conjoint de lutte contre le trafic des migrants et la traite des personnes au Sénégal
SAFIRE (Consortium Croix rouge française) Parcours d’insertion socioprofessionnelle et vers l’emploi (PISE)
summary:
Trait d'union géographique et culturel entre l'Afrique noire et le Maghreb, pays Sahélien situé au bord de l’Océan Atlantique, la Mauritanie est à la fois un pays de transit et de destination des migrants.
Suite aux différentes crises alimentaires et nutritionnelles successives dues notamment à la sècheresse, son milieu rural souffre d'un important exode vers les villes, dans l'espoir de sources de revenus complémentaires, d’emploi voire de migrations transfrontalières.
Le programme SAFIRE a été élaboré en réponse aux problématiques suivantes:
Les dynamiques migratoires : L’exode rural est très important en Mauritanie. Les Migrations sont saisonnières ou de longue durée, internes ou transfrontalières, vers les villes, les pays de la sous-région, l'Europe et l’Amérique. Les migrants entretiennent généralement un lien économique et social important avec leur village d’origine. Les dynamiques migratoires internes représentent ainsi des opportunités économiques insuffisamment valorisées.
Le contexte urbain : Les centres urbains, et particulièrement la ville de Nouakchott, ont connu une croissance démographique exponentielle et rapide depuis quelques décennies.
 Le secteur informel, qui nourrit plus de 80% de la population urbaine en Mauritanie, ne représenterait que 30% de l’économie de Nouakchott.
 L'emploi est aujourd'hui la principale préoccupation des jeunes. Il existe peu de formations professionnelles pour les jeunes déscolarisés ; celles qui existent ne sont pas toujours adaptées aux besoins du marché du travail local.
partner_implementing: Migration Citoyenneté Développement, Terre des Hommes Italia, ECO-Développement, Croissant rouge mauritanien, Croix rouge française

title: SAFIRE (Consortium GRET) Projet d’appui à l’inclusion économique et sociale pour la stabilité et l’emploi des jeunes en Mauritanie – PIESSE
summary:
Trait d'union géographique et culturel entre l'Afrique noire et le Maghreb, pays Sahélien situé au bord de l’Océan Atlantique, la Mauritanie est à la fois un pays de transit et de destination des migrants.
